comment_text: The possibility of an unmanned Starship going to Mars in 2022, I would say, approaches zero.  There's still a major amount of development to be done.   Super Heavy...not even a mockup or intitial test article yet.  Still waiting for a hop of the full Starship tanking system body.  I know development is fast, but it's too slow and failure-plagued for 2022, or really even 2024.  Would be lucky to see orbital flight by 2022.  And manned rating?  I'm just not sure that can ever happen.  Need like 100 perfect Starship reentry and landings in a row, in my opinion.  They are still describing Falcon9 booster landings as, "hope to have a landing".  If they could get Starship to orbit by 2022 with functioning, but unoccupied crew section, then I would say build a fleet of 5 and launch one of them about every 3 to 5 days for a year, with no more than one lost vehicle, and only within the first 15 launches...just to rapidly  build the necessary confidence in the vehicle design.  Would it take several on orbit refuelings of a Starship, just to have it do a circumlunar mission?  If so, not sure this is the way to go.  I think Starship might be a shuttle craft.  Keep a dozen on Earth and send a dozen to Mars to serve as Martian shuttles from Martian surface to Mars orbit and back.  Maybe something that never touches atmosphere should make the trips from Earth to Mars and back.

i don't think starship will go to mars... instead, there will be a mars-specific (or even interplanetary-specific) craft that makes that particular journey. i predict that starship will be used exclusively for hauling people, supplies, and fuel too and from low-earth orbit (and maybe a quick publicity jaunt to the moon!)

it makes no sense to send to mars a vessel that has been fine tuned for earth. that's potentially a lot of extra unused mass, and every gram counts!

Regarding shooting a bullet pro-grade from the ISS and hitting yourself in the back: ignoring orbital procession, drag, reboost, etc, as long as the resulting orbital period of the bullet to the ISS orbital period is a rational number, it will eventually hit you.
If you launched straight up with enough ∆V you would end up in a solar orbit and then if you kept going you would end up in a galactic orbit. I tried it once in Kerbal so believe me I'm an expert. /s
